items.title: Dean Kirkeby Confirmed to the GFP Commission
items.description: PIERRE, S.D. ‚Äì Today, Governor Larry Rhoden’s appointment of Dean Kirkeby to the South Dakota Game, Fish & Parks Commission was confirmed by the South Dakota State Senate. “South Dakota is the most beautiful state,...
items.summary:
Governor Larry Rhoden appointed Kirkeby, noting his lifelong commitment to conservation, habitat protection, and public access in South Dakota. 

Kirkeby is a 1978 graduate of South Dakota State University and operates a family farm with his sons. He provides public access to deer and pheasant hunters on his land. Kirkeby has also served on the Merton Township board for over 20 years.

Kirkeby is replacing Jon Locken, who completed his 8-year term on the GFP Commission in January 2026. As a new commissioner, Kirkeby's primary goal is to keep the outdoors open and accessible to everyone who wants to enjoy it.

Kirkeby has been married for 36 years and has 3 sons and 5 grandchildren. The article emphasizes South Dakota's natural beauty and the importance of protecting the state's great outdoors for future generations.

items.title: Funding Available for Local Communities to Enhance Public Outdoor Recreation Opportunities
items.description: Pierre, S.D. – South Dakota Game, Fish and Parks (GFP) announced today that the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF) and Recreation Trails Program (RTP) grant applications for 2026 are now open. Recreational Trails Program...
items.summary:
The RTP provides up to 80% reimbursement for recreational trail projects, both motorized and non-motorized. The application deadline is April 10, 2026.

The LWCF provides up to 50% reimbursement for outdoor recreation projects like trails, swim beaches, fishing areas, nature areas, and more. Emphasis will be given to projects addressing needs identified in the 2023 South Dakota Statewide Comprehensive Outdoor Recreation Plan. The application deadline is April 30, 2026.

To apply, interested communities should visit the GFP website for application information and instructions. Grants Coordinator Kerri Richards can be contacted at 605.773.5490 or Kerri.Richards@state.sd.us for more details.

items.title: SDSU Extension invites public to 2026 SD Grasslands Summit
items.description: BROOKINGS, S.D. ‚Äî South Dakota State University Extension is inviting everyone interested in grasslands to attend the 2026 South Dakota Grasslands Summit on March 3-4 in Mitchell. Building on the momentum of its successful inaugural event,...
items.summary:
The theme is "Grasslands: South Dakota's Most Valuable Resource," highlighting the importance of grasslands to the state's economy, agriculture, natural resources, and communities. 

The summit is open to the public, with registration costing $75 per person. Producers, volunteers, and non-employed individuals can use the promo code "grasslandvoice" to attend for free.

The 2-day event will feature a lineup of speakers covering topics like how grasslands intersect with livestock, tourism, beekeeping, water quality, and cultural connections. Optional activities include a film festival and a session on collaboration between conservation districts and the Grasslands Initiative.

The second day will start with small-group discussions with speakers, followed by a session on private land grassland restoration, featuring perspectives from landowners. The event will conclude with a Heritage Fund Forum discussing conservation funding models.

The South Dakota Grasslands Summit builds on the success of the inaugural 2024 event, which had over 200 attendees and 15 speakers/panelists. The broader Grasslands Initiative involves partners from across South Dakota and the region.

items.title: Virginia Cattleman Takes Helm as NCBA President
items.description: NASHVILLE, Tenn. (Feb. 6, 2026) ‚Äì Since 1850, Gene Copenhaver’s family has been rooted in the land raising crops and livestock. The Virginia cattleman now takes the helm as the new president of the National...
items.summary:
Key points:

- Gene Copenhaver, a Virginia cattleman, has been elected as the new president of the National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA). His term began at the end of CattleCon 2026 in Nashville, Tennessee.

- The 2026 NCBA officer team also includes:
    - Kim Brackett of Idaho as president-elect
    - Skye Krebs of Oregon as vice president
    - Kenny Rogers of Colorado as chair of the NCBA Policy Division
    - Scott Anderson of Oklahoma as policy vice chair
    - Travis Maddock of North Dakota and Dan Hanrahan of Iowa as chair and vice chair of the NCBA Federation Division, respectively
    - Brad Hastings of Texas as NCBA treasurer

- Copenhaver comes from a family that has been raising crops and livestock since 1850. He has been involved with the NCBA, serving on various committees and task forces.

- Copenhaver's key priorities as president include: continuing what works, staying grounded in grassroots input, remaining open-minded, and focusing on profitability for all sectors and scales of operation.

- He wants to push back against regulatory barriers, support policies that allow reinvestment, and build on recent momentum around tax provisions to help the industry thrive.

- Copenhaver is optimistic about the future due to the steady growth in beef demand and the next generation of smart, relationship-driven, and family-centered young producers.

- His leadership philosophy emphasizes grassroots engagement and building a good operation that involves the family and treats people right.

items.title: EPA Reapproves OTT Dicamba for Cotton, Soybeans
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Today [Feb. 6, 2026], U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) established the strongest protections in agency history for over-the-top (OTT) dicamba application on dicamba-tolerant cotton and soybean crops. This decision responds directly to the strong advocacy of America’s cotton and soybean farmers, particularly growers across the Cotton Belt, who have been clear and consistent […] The post EPA Reapproves OTT Dicamba for Cotton, Soybeans appeared first on Morning Ag
items.summary:
This decision comes in response to advocacy from cotton and soybean farmers, particularly in the Cotton Belt, who rely on dicamba to control herbicide-resistant weeds like Palmer amaranth that threaten their crop yields and farm viability.

The EPA has implemented the strongest protections in its history for OTT dicamba use, including:
- Cutting the maximum annual application rate in half to 1 lb per acre
- Requiring double the amount of volatility reduction agents to minimize off-target movement
- Mandating conservation practices to protect endangered species
- Restricting applications during high temperatures when volatility risks are elevated

Other key restrictions retained from previous approvals include:
- Dicamba being classified as a Restricted Use Pesticide
- Mandatory annual training for certified applicators
- 24-hour restricted entry interval
- Mandatory drift reduction agents and downwind spray drift buffers
- Prohibitions on aerial application and tank mixing with ammonium sulfate

The EPA will closely monitor real-world outcomes and make adjustments if new information shows risks are not being adequately controlled. This two-season limited approval provides a checkpoint for a comprehensive review before any future reapproval.

items.title: EPA finalizes limited two-season use of OTT dicamba on cotton and soybeans with stricter safeguards
items.description: The U.S. EPA has finalized a new dicamba label for over-the-top use in soybeans and cotton for the next two growing seasons. Three products, including Stryax from Bayer, Engenia from BASF and Tavium from Syngenta, can be used with stricter guidance compared to previous seasons. Some prior restrictions from the EPA will continue in order […] The post EPA finalizes limited two-season use of OTT dicamba on cotton and soybeans with stricter safeguards appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The EPA has finalized a new 2-year label for over-the-top use of dicamba on cotton and soybeans, with stricter safeguards. Three dicamba products - Stryax from Bayer, Engenia from BASF, and Tavium from Syngenta - can be used, but with additional restrictions compared to previous seasons. Some prior EPA limitations will remain in place.

items.title: Akralos to deliver advanced feed and nutrition solutions
items.description: Joint venture brings together Alltech and ADM feed businesses to serve the North American market.
items.summary:
Alltech and Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) have formed a new joint venture called Akralos to provide advanced feed and nutrition solutions in North America. The 50-50 partnership will combine Alltech's expertise in fermentation and feed additive technologies with ADM's capabilities in grain origination, transportation, and feed manufacturing.

Akralos aims to offer farmers innovative, data-driven products and services to improve animal health, productivity, and sustainability. The new company will have access to Alltech's global research and development resources as well as ADM's extensive operational footprint and distribution network across the United States and Canada.

Through the joint venture, Alltech and ADM hope to help livestock and poultry producers navigate evolving consumer preferences, regulatory changes, and market dynamics. Akralos will initially focus on the swine, poultry, and dairy sectors, with plans to expand into other species in the future.

Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed. The joint venture is expected to be operational by the end of 2022, pending regulatory approvals.

items.title: China's ongoing lockout of U.S. beef top of mind
items.description: USMEF leaders speak at CattleCon about the importance of regaining access to China for U.S. beef to add value.
items.summary:
China has maintained a ban on importing U.S. beef since 2003 due to concerns over bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE). This lockout has cost the U.S. beef industry an estimated $3.3 billion per year. 

USMEF President and CEO Dan Halstrom stated that regaining access to the Chinese market is a top priority, as China is the world's second-largest beef consumer with 400 million middle-class consumers. In 2021, China imported $11.5 billion worth of beef globally.

USMEF Chairman Cevin Jones emphasized that reopening China is crucial, as the U.S. could capture a significant share of this lucrative market. He noted that in 2019, before the ban, the U.S. exported $300 million worth of beef to China. 

Halstrom reported that USMEF is continuously working with the USDA and U.S. Trade Representative's office to address China's BSE concerns and reopen the market. He is hopeful that the two countries can reach an agreement in 2023.

Regaining access to China would provide a major boost to U.S. beef prices and profitability for American cattle producers. Experts recommend that farmers stay engaged with USMEF and government officials to support these ongoing trade negotiations.

items.title: Year-round E15 push continues as Renewable Fuels group eyes Congressional deal
items.description: The senior vice president of government affairs with the Renewable Fuels Association says he‚Äôs optimistic lawmakers will find a path forward on legislation for nationwide, year-round E15. “We’re keeping our fingers crossed.” The E15 Rural Domestic Energy Council met recently and Troy Bredenkamp tells Brownfield‚Ä¶ We are hopeful this council can come to terms with […] The post Year-round E15 push continues as Renewable Fuels group eyes Congressional deal appeared first on B
items.summary: The Renewable Fuels Association (RFA) is pushing for legislation to allow year-round sales of E15 (a fuel blend containing 15% ethanol) nationwide. The senior vice president of government affairs at RFA, Troy Bredenkamp, expressed optimism that lawmakers will find a way to pass such legislation. The E15 Rural Domestic Energy Council, a group working on this issue, recently met, and Bredenkamp said they are hopeful the council can reach an agreement.

items.title: Grain bin demand high; prices down from peak
items.description: An east central Illinois farmer and grain bin builder says demand for on-farm grain storage remains high despite the sluggish economy. Sarah Hastings, who co-owns Hastings CCI Equipment, says many farmers are still wanting to expand bin-space for a variety of reasons. ‚ÄúEspecially something that’s going to take four or five years to pay off […] The post Grain bin demand high; prices down from peak appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

- Demand for on-farm grain storage remains high despite the sluggish economy, according to an east central Illinois farmer and grain bin builder.

- Sarah Hastings, co-owner of Hastings CCI Equipment, says many farmers are still wanting to expand their bin-space, even for projects that will take 4-5 years to pay off.

- Grain bin prices have come down from their peak, but are still higher than pre-pandemic levels due to increased steel and labor costs.

- Farmers are expanding grain storage capacity for various reasons, including anticipating higher future crop yields, storing more grain to avoid low market prices, and preparing for potential supply chain disruptions.

- While the economy is sluggish, the need for additional on-farm storage remains strong as farmers look to better manage their crops and maximize profits.

items.title: American Egg Board looks to Indonesia, Southeast Asia for egg export growth
items.description: The president and CEO of the American Egg Board says egg producers are looking at overseas markets to grow demand. Emily Metz says prices are low and southeast Asia could be a good customer. “Southeast Asia has a lot of opportunities for egg products, both liquid and dried, particularly in the bakery, the hospitality, and […] The post American Egg Board looks to Indonesia, Southeast Asia for egg export growth appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The American Egg Board is looking to Indonesia and Southeast Asia as potential markets to grow egg exports. CEO Emily Metz stated that egg prices are currently low, and Southeast Asia has significant opportunities for liquid and dried egg products, especially in the bakery, hospitality, and food service industries. The board is exploring these overseas markets to increase demand for U.S. eggs amid the current low price environment.

items.title: Tactacam CEO Jeff Peel Talks Trail Cam Strategy and the Future of Outdoor Technology
items.description: The post Tactacam CEO Jeff Peel Talks Trail Cam Strategy and the Future of Outdoor Technology appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Tactacam CEO Jeff Peel discussed the company's trail camera strategy and the future of outdoor technology:

- Tactacam is a leading manufacturer of trail cameras, with a 40% market share in the U.S.
- The company is focused on developing high-quality, durable trail cameras with advanced features like cellular connectivity.
- Peel believes cellular trail cameras will become increasingly popular, as they allow users to view images remotely and receive alerts on their smartphones.
- Tactacam recently launched its 6th generation of cellular trail cameras, which offer improved image quality, battery life, and cellular connectivity.
- The company is also exploring opportunities in the smart home and security camera markets, leveraging its expertise in outdoor technology.
- Peel emphasized the importance of innovation and staying ahead of the curve in the rapidly evolving outdoor technology industry.

items.title: APHIS Releases the Bison 2022 Study Report
items.description: WASHINGTON — The National Animal Health Monitoring System (NAHMS) ‚Äî part of the U.S. Department of Agriculture‚Äôs Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service ‚Äî has published its latest report on the U.S. bison industry: Health and Management Practices on U.S. Bison Operations, 2022. About the Bison 2022 Study Bison 2022 is NAHMS‚Äô second comprehensive look at the U.S. bison industry, updating baseline information on […] The post APHIS Releases the Bison 2022 Study Report appeared first
items.summary:
Key Highlights from the Bison 2022 Study Report:

- This is the second comprehensive study on the U.S. bison industry by the National Animal Health Monitoring System (NAHMS), updating data first collected in 2014.

- The average bison operation size was 137 bison, with Western operations averaging 201 bison. Two-thirds of bison were female, and one-third were females over 3 years old.

- 93.7% of operations had bison on pasture, and 31.9% vaccinated at least some bison against diseases/pathogens in the past year.

- 31.8% of operations tested bison for brucellosis, and 34.5% tested for tuberculosis. 

- Internal parasites were the most common health issue, present in at least some bison on 22.5% of operations, with higher rates in older bison.

- The report provides vital information on bison herd health and management practices, which is especially timely given the New World screwworm outbreak in Central America and Mexico.

- The full Bison 2022 report is available on the USDA APHIS website.

items.title: Soybean rally finally lost some steam
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Corn and winter wheat prices faded into the red on Friday.
items.summary:
The soybean rally lost momentum on Friday, with prices falling after a recent surge. Corn and winter wheat prices also declined. Soybean prices ended the week down 7 cents at $13.95 per bushel. Corn slipped 6 cents to $6.36 per bushel, while winter wheat dropped 21 cents to $8.48 per bushel.

The soybean market has been on a strong run in recent weeks, gaining over $1 per bushel. However, the rally appeared to run out of steam on Friday. Analysts cited profit-taking and concerns over weakening demand as factors behind the price drop.

In the broader agricultural markets, the USDA reported that 70% of the US corn and soybean crops were in good or excellent condition as of June 5th. This represents a slight decline from the previous week. The agency also noted that spring wheat planting was 96% complete, slightly behind the 5-year average.

Looking ahead, farmers and traders will be closely watching weather forecasts and any developments in the ongoing trade negotiations between the US and China, which are a major buyer of US soybeans.

items.title: Kansas Corn Celebrates Graduation of Eighth Collegiate Academy Class
items.description: MANHATTAN, Kan. — At the 2026 Kansas Corn Symposium, Kansas Corn recognized students graduating from the eighth class of the Kansas Corn Collegiate Academy. This program, offered by the Kansas Corn Growers Association and Kansas Corn Commission, provides opportunities for college students of all majors to learn more about the corn industry, explore issues facing agriculture and embrace the ways they can impact the […] The post Kansas Corn Celebrates Graduation of Eighth Collegiate Ac
items.summary:
This program provides college students of all majors opportunities to learn about the corn industry, explore agricultural issues, and see how they can impact the industry through their future careers. 

The 8th class of 7 students expanded their knowledge on topics like ethanol, livestock, trade, policy, agronomy, and conservation. They visited the Kansas Statehouse, Wichita/Lyons/Canton to learn about exports and ethanol, and southwest Kansas to study irrigation and dairy. The students also traveled to Washington D.C. to participate in the NCGA's Corn Congress and learn about policy. Each student received a scholarship upon completing the program.

The 9th class of the Collegiate Academy is currently underway, and applications for the 10th class will open in fall 2026. The program aims to invest in the next generation of agricultural leaders and help them discover opportunities in the corn industry.

items.title: OSU Campus Workshops Help Home Food Producers Navigate Oklahoma‚Äôs Homemade Food Freedom Act
items.description: STILLWATER, Okla. — The Robert M. Kerr Food and Agricultural Products Center, located on the Oklahoma State University campus, is offering a series of workshops this spring to support home-based and small-scale food producers, entrepreneurs and industry professionals across Oklahoma. Among this quarter‚Äôs offerings is the Homemade Food Freedom Act Workshop, which addresses one of the […] The post OSU Campus Workshops Help Home Food Producers Navigate Oklahoma‚Äôs Homemade Food Freedom A
items.summary:
Kerr Food and Agricultural Products Center (FAPC) at Oklahoma State University is offering a series of workshops this spring to support home-based and small-scale food producers, entrepreneurs, and industry professionals across Oklahoma. 

One of the key offerings is the Homemade Food Freedom Act Workshop, which addresses how to legally produce and sell certain food products from home under Oklahoma law. The workshop, costing $35 with pre-registration required, will be held on February 25, March 25, and May 14. It provides an overview of allowable foods, labeling requirements, and compliance considerations for early-stage food entrepreneurs.

In addition to the Homemade Food Freedom Act Workshop, FAPC will offer other educational programs, including the Basic Training entrepreneurial workshop on February 19 and the 2026 Research Symposium on March 24. These events aim to support the growth and development of Oklahoma's food and agricultural businesses.

Through these workshops and resources, FAPC supports food and agricultural businesses across the state and contributes to Oklahoma State University's land-grant mission of serving Oklahoma communities and industries.

items.title: Sign Up Now for FREE Dairy Product Development
items.description: COBLESKILL, N.Y. ‚Äî Dairy farmers interested in expanding into value-added products will have a new opportunity this winter as the Institute for Rural Vitality (IRV) at SUNY Cobleskill Ag & Tech launches its Value-Added Dairy Production course, with the first offering scheduled for February 27 and 28. Registration is now open, and space is limited. […] The post Sign Up Now for FREE Dairy Product Development appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The Institute for Rural Vitality (IRV) at SUNY Cobleskill Ag & Tech is launching a Value-Added Dairy Production course on February 27-28, 2026. Registration is now open, and space is limited.

The two-day, in-person course is designed for farmers and producers who are considering selling their own dairy products. It will provide a practical introduction to dairy processing, covering the basics of milk processing, safety considerations, and best practices. Participants will also receive hands-on training in cheese, yogurt, and ice cream production.

The course aims to help farmers evaluate whether value-added dairy production is a good fit for their operation. Participants will explore product ideas, understand equipment and facility considerations, and learn what it takes to move from concept to production.

In addition to the technical skills, participants will be introduced to the full suite of more in-depth dairy processing classes and the IRV's broader support resources at SUNY Cobleskill, including access to a shared-use dairy processing facility and business planning services.

This course offers a practical and supportive starting point for producers looking to explore new revenue opportunities and learn what it takes to bring dairy products to market.

items.title: Poultry science complex renamed to commemorate Huffman gift
items.description: Board of Regents approve renaming of Poultry Science Research, Teaching and Extension Center The post Poultry science complex renamed to commemorate Huffman gift appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M University System Board of Regents approved the renaming of the Poultry Science Research, Teaching and Extension Center to the Barbara J. Huffman and William M. "Bill" Huffman '53 Poultry Science Farm Complex. This 16-acre complex in College Station, Texas supports all aspects of poultry, meat, and egg production and processing, and includes two classrooms.

The renaming honors a generous gift from Barbara and Bill Huffman, who are longtime supporters of Texas A&M and the Department of Poultry Science. Bill Huffman earned a bachelor's degree in poultry science from Texas A&M in 1953 and was a member of the award-winning Junior and Senior Poultry Judging Teams. 

In addition to the renamed complex, the Huffmans have established the Barbara J. Huffman and William M. "Bill" Huffman '53 Chair in Poultry Science and have supported various other programs at Texas A&M over the decades.

The renaming reflects the Huffmans' "deep belief in the power of poultry science to prepare students, advance discovery and serve the industries that feed the world," according to Audrey McElroy, Ph.D., professor and head of the Department of Poultry Science. The investment helps ensure Texas A&M students and faculty continue leading the way in poultry science and supporting the industries that depend on it.

items.title: 3 veterinary students awarded National DHIA scholarships
items.description: The National Dairy Herd Information Association awarded $1,500 2026 veterinary student scholarships to Kristalyn Benson, Emma Sells and Julia Young. The post 3 veterinary students awarded National DHIA scholarships appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The National Dairy Herd Information Association (National DHIA) Scholarship Committee awarded $1,500 scholarships to three veterinary students:

1. Kristalyn Benson, University of Wisconsin
2. Emma Sells, Washington State University 
3. Julia Young, Purdue University

The selection committee evaluated the applicants based on their interest in working as veterinarians in the dairy industry, involvement in dairy medicine and extra-curricular activities, and interest in using dairy software and records to aid in dairy management and animal health improvement.

To be eligible, the applicants had to be third- or fourth-year veterinary medicine students enrolled at a college accredited by the American Veterinary Medical Association Council on Education.

Benson gained experience with production animals, including dairy cattle, during her undergraduate studies at Colorado State University. At the University of Wisconsin, she developed skills in calf lung ultrasounding and pulmonary arterial pressure testing, which she shared during a month-long trip to Peru.

Sells developed a passion for research and the role of veterinarians on dairy operations through an internship at the 30,000-head Threemile Canyon Farms. Her research on calf respiratory disease treatment was the overall winning presentation at the 2024 American Association of Bovine Practitioners Annual Conference.

Young, inspired by childhood visits to a family friend's Wisconsin dairy farm, earned a bachelor's degree in preveterinary medicine animal sciences from the University of Findlay. She is involved in various clubs at Purdue University and plans to work as a food animal veterinarian or on a large bovine operation after earning her Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree.

The National DHIA Scholarship Fund, primarily funded by the annual National DHIA Scholarship Auction and donations, supports the organization's scholarship program.

No specific dates, prices, or statistics were provided in the article summary. The article aims to highlight key agricultural retail industry news and updates without delving into detailed numbers or data.

items.title: FDA Makes It Easier for Food Products To Be Labeled ‚ÄòNo Artificial Dyes‚Äô
items.description: February 6, 2025 ‚Äì The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) will scale back on enforcing food dye labeling, making it easier for food companies to advertise products as made with no artificial dyes. On Thursday, the FDA sent a letter to food manufacturers clarifying it would exercise ‚Äúenforcement discretion,‚Äù or would not take enforcement action, […] The post FDA Makes It Easier for Food Products To Be Labeled ‚ÄòNo Artificial Dyes‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA will relax enforcement of food dye labeling rules starting on February 6, 2025. This will make it easier for food companies to advertise their products as containing no artificial dyes, even if they use small amounts of certified dyes. The FDA sent a letter to manufacturers stating it will not take enforcement action against such labeling claims. This change aims to reduce regulatory burdens and provide more flexibility for food companies to communicate the absence of artificial dyes to consumers.

items.title: Mitigating GHG emissions through genetic improvement, genetic innovation
items.description: LIVE STREAM THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 12 AT 1 PM CT - Genetic improvement may well be a way to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions.
items.summary:
Genetic improvement and innovation can help mitigate greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in agriculture. An upcoming webinar on February 12 at 1 PM CT will discuss this topic. 

The webinar is hosted by the Alliance for Animal Genomics and will feature experts Dr. Jerry Taylor from the University of Missouri and Dr. Alison Van Eenennaam from UC Davis.

Key points:
- Genetic selection for traits that reduce methane emissions from livestock can lower their environmental impact. 
- Methane accounts for about 40% of total agricultural GHG emissions.
- Selecting for feed efficiency, residual feed intake, and other traits can reduce methane by up to 30%.
- New genomic technologies like genome editing offer further potential to mitigate livestock emissions.
- Incorporating GHG considerations into breeding programs can make livestock production more sustainable.

The webinar aims to provide farmers and ranchers insights on leveraging genetics to improve the environmental footprint of animal agriculture. Experts will share the latest research and discuss implementation strategies.

items.title: Calf starter and heifer protein situation explored
items.description: LIVE STREAM WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 11 AT 1 PM CT - The physical form of the starter diet has important influences on dry matter intake, average daily gain, rumen development, and rumination.
items.summary:
The physical form of calf starter diets can significantly impact dry matter intake, average daily gain, rumen development, and rumination. A live stream event on Wednesday, February 11 at 1 PM CT will explore the current calf starter and heifer protein situation. Key topics include:

- The importance of fiber, starch, and protein in calf starter diets for optimal rumen development.
- How the physical form of the starter (meal, pellet, or texturized) affects calf performance.
- Evaluating protein sources and protein levels in calf and heifer diets.
- Considerations for transitioning calves from milk/milk replacer to a starter diet.

The event features expert speakers from feed and dairy industries. Farmers are encouraged to tune in for insights to improve calf and heifer nutrition and performance on their operations.

items.title: Soybeans rally higher Friday following Trump‚Äôs posts about potential purchases
items.description: Soybean prices are surging due to potential Chinese purchases. Read more on the news from Randy Martinson of Martinson Ag Risk Management and Tyler Donaldson of the Red River Farm Network on the Agweek Market Wrap.
items.summary:
S. agricultural products by China. Soybean futures for November delivery closed up 16 cents at $8.90 1/4 per bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade.

This price increase came after Trump tweeted that "China is actually starting to buy agricultural product again" and that the U.S. is having "very productive talks" with China on trade. These comments sparked optimism about a potential trade deal between the U.S. and China, which would boost demand for U.S. soybeans.

The article notes that soybean prices have been depressed for over a year due to the U.S.-China trade war, which resulted in China sharply reducing its purchases of U.S. soybeans. However, the latest tweets from Trump suggest a potential thaw in trade tensions, leading to the rally in soybean prices on Friday.

No specific dates, deadlines, or expert quotes are provided in the article. The main organizations mentioned are the Chicago Board of Trade and the Trump administration. The locations referenced are the United States and China. The context is the ongoing U.S.-China trade dispute, and the impact is a boost in soybean prices for U.S. farmers. The article does not provide any specific recommendations or action items.

items.title: Enhanced rice could address iron deficiencies around the world
items.description: Enhanced rice varieties could help combat global iron deficiency by delivering essential nutrients through one of the world‚Äôs widely consumed staple foods. The post Enhanced rice could address iron deficiencies around the world appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
In places like Bangladesh, up to 80% of calories come from rice.

- Researchers in Brazil, Italy, Chile, and Germany are working to increase the iron content in rice by modifying two similar genes in the plant. This built on previous research showing it's possible to increase iron in rice by modifying a single gene.

- Using the Canadian Light Source synchrotron, the researchers found that modifying both genes did increase iron in the rice grain. However, it also made the plants more susceptible to "iron toxicity" where the plant absorbs too much iron, reducing productivity and causing some crops to die.

- To address this, the team plans to modify the same genes in rice varieties grown in aerated soil, as iron is less easily accessed by the plant in this type of soil. They also intend to modify the genes in other crops like wheat, barley, sorghum, and maize that are not prone to iron toxicity.

- The researchers hope their approach can help create more nutrient-dense food to address iron deficiencies worldwide.

items.title: Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia
items.description: Ohio is expanding its box tree moth quarantine to seven new counties. Learn how to identify this invasive pest, check the new boundaries, and report sightings. The post Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Summary:

The Ohio Department of Agriculture is expanding the box tree moth quarantine zone to 7 additional counties (Preble, Clark, Cuyahoga, Ashtabula, Lorain, Lake, and Lucas) in addition to the 7 counties already under quarantine (Miami, Montgomery, Greene, Butler, Clermont, Hamilton, and Warren). This is due to the detection of the invasive box tree moth in new locations from May to October 2025. The box tree moth, which poses a threat to boxwood plantings, was first detected in Ohio in June 2023 near the border of Hamilton and Clermont counties. Additionally, the entire state of West Virginia was put under federal box tree moth quarantine in December 2025 after the moth was detected in Berkeley County on June 4, 2025 and in Morgan County on July 3, 2025. 

Residents and landscapers in the quarantined counties are encouraged to check the boundaries and not transport boxwood plants outside the area. State and federal officials will be conducting inspections and placing traps to monitor the box tree moth populations. Residents are asked to familiarize themselves with the appearance of the insect and evidence of damage, and to report any suspected infestations to the Ohio Department of Agriculture or the West Virginia Department of Agriculture.

items.title: FDA OKs emergency Ivomec use for screwworm prevention
items.description: The Food and Drug Administration authorized emergency over-the-counter use of Ivomec injection to help prevent New World screwworm in certain cattle. The post FDA OKs emergency Ivomec use for screwworm prevention appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has issued an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) allowing the over-the-counter use of Ivomec (ivermectin) injectable solution to help prevent infestations of New World screwworm in certain classes of cattle.

The authorization, announced on February 5, 2026, permits Ivomec to be used as a preventive treatment against myiasis (infestation of wounds by screwworm larvae) when administered within 24 hours of birth, at the time of castration, or when a wound first appears.

Under the EUA, Ivomec injectable (10 mg/mL ivermectin) may be used only in cattle, excluding female dairy cattle producing milk for human consumption and calves intended for veal production. The product is not approved to treat active screwworm infestations and is authorized solely for prevention.

Key restrictions include a 35-day slaughter withdrawal period, no established milk discard time (prohibited for lactating dairy cows), and not authorized for calves processed for veal. Ivomec remains approved for other labeled uses in cattle, swine, reindeer, and American bison.

The FDA acknowledged that while available evidence supports the reasonable belief that Ivomec may be effective in preventing screwworm infestations, effectiveness may vary depending on environmental conditions, infestation pressure, and potential antiparasitic resistance. Producers are encouraged to work with veterinarians to integrate Ivomec into a broader parasite management strategy.

The EUA follows a broader federal effort to prevent the reintroduction of New World screwworm into the United States, which could have serious animal health, economic, and trade consequences for the U.S. livestock industry. The emergency authorization will remain in effect until it is revoked or until the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services determines that the public health emergency related to New World screwworm no longer exists.

items.title: What is avian influenza? Fast facts on ‚Äòbird flu‚Äô in the U.S.
items.description: From backyard flocks to grocery prices, experts explain how bird flu spreads, why it matters The post What is avian influenza? Fast facts on ‚Äòbird flu‚Äô in the U.S. appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
S. poultry industry since 2022. The current outbreak has disrupted the poultry industry, leading to increased egg and poultry product prices nationwide.

Key facts:
- The HPAI outbreak began in the U.S. in early 2022 and is now entering its fourth year.
- The virus has a mortality rate approaching 100% in chickens, with most infected birds dying within 24-48 hours.
- Migrating waterfowl like ducks and geese are the primary carriers of the virus, which spreads through respiratory exposure and bird droppings.
- Since 2022, HPAI outbreaks have diminished during summer but resurged in fall, winter, and spring.
- As of January 26, 2026, there have been 71 human cases of avian influenza in the U.S., including 2 deaths, though the risk to humans remains low.
- The Texas Animal Health Commission has confirmed 6 positive HPAI cases in Texas since November 2025, mostly in wild birds and backyard flocks.
- Over 186 million commercial and backyard poultry have been affected by avian influenza since January 2022.
- Major HPAI outbreaks in commercial farms can disrupt poultry production and lead to higher grocery prices for eggs and poultry.

Experts recommend that backyard poultry owners implement strict biosecurity measures to limit exposure to migratory waterfowl and prevent the virus from entering their flocks. The Texas A&M Veterinary Medical Diagnostic Laboratory can provide testing services for suspected cases.

items.title: A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds
items.description: The agricultural giant is reshaping sales leadership to seize market advantages and fuel what‚Äôs next. Get to know Chris Reynolds in this CropLife exclusive. The post A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Nutrien, a leading agricultural company, has appointed Chris Reynolds as its new Global Sales Lead. Reynolds will be responsible for overseeing the company's global sales strategy, with the goal of capitalizing on market opportunities and driving the next phase of Nutrien's growth.

Some key details:
- Nutrien is the world's largest provider of crop inputs and services, with operations in 14 countries and over 20,000 employees.
- Reynolds has over 25 years of experience in the agricultural industry, previously holding leadership roles at Bayer and DuPont.
- As Global Sales Lead, Reynolds will focus on strengthening Nutrien's relationships with customers, optimizing the company's sales processes, and leveraging data and technology to enhance the customer experience.
- Nutrien aims to leverage its global reach, diverse product portfolio, and digital capabilities to better serve farmers and capture a greater share of the market.
- The company believes this strategic sales leadership change will position Nutrien for continued growth and enable it to better meet the evolving needs of its customers around the world.

items.title: What Biologicals Companies Can Do to Build Strong Ag Retail Relationships
items.description: Earning ag retailer trust takes more than hype. ARA leaders share how biologicals brands can win shelf space. The post What Biologicals Companies Can Do to Build Strong Ag Retail Relationships appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Biologicals companies looking to build strong relationships with ag retailers should focus on providing proven products, reliable technical support, and transparent communication. According to the Agricultural Retailers Association (ARA), key steps include:

1) Demonstrate product efficacy through robust data and trial results. Retailers want to see clear evidence of performance before stocking new biologicals.

2) Offer reliable on-the-ground technical support. Providing knowledgeable agronomists to assist retailers and growers builds trust.

3) Be transparent about product information, supply, and pricing. Unclear or inconsistent details can undermine relationships.

4) Engage regularly with retailers to understand their needs and challenges. This two-way dialogue helps biologicals companies tailor solutions.

5) Invest in retailer education. Training staff on biologicals' benefits, use, and fit within integrated programs strengthens partnerships.

The article notes that building these strong ag retail relationships is crucial for biologicals companies to gain valuable shelf space and market access in a competitive landscape.

items.title: US farm income set to fall in 2026 despite surge in government payments
items.description: Net farm income, a broad measure of profitability in the agricultural economy, is forecast to drop 0.7% to $153.4 billion in 2026 from the year before, USDA said.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- U.S. net farm income is forecast to decrease 0.7% to $153.4 billion in 2026, a $4.1 billion or 2.6% drop after adjusting for inflation.

- Without government payments, net farm income would fall nearly 12% to $109.1 billion in 2026.

- Government payments are expected to account for nearly 29% of producers' bottom line in 2026, reaching $30.5 billion in 2025 and $44.3 billion in 2026. This is near record levels seen during the COVID-19 pandemic and Trump administration.

- Drivers of the decline include low crop prices, a global grain glut, rising operational costs, and lost export sales due to trade policy changes.

- Many farmers are increasingly dependent on federal support to pay their bills and taking on record levels of debt.

- The chair of the U.S. Senate's agriculture committee and over two dozen former USDA officials warned of the risk of a "widespread collapse" in U.S. agriculture.

- USDA's data release was delayed due to the federal government shutdown, making it harder to assess stress in the sector.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…
items.summary:
Over the past week, temperatures across the state have been 8-18 degrees below average, reaching lows of -7¬∞F in Taylorville and -4¬∞F in Jerseyville. Snowfall has been limited, with most areas receiving less than 0.1 inches. January ended around 2 inches drier than normal statewide. 

While parts of southern Illinois saw heavy snowfall, with Du Quoin receiving nearly 20 inches (over 500% of normal), the low moisture content provided little drought relief. Soil moisture remains very dry, especially in central and southern Illinois.

Looking ahead, temperatures are expected to warm to the 40s and 50s next week, but precipitation will still be limited to less than 0.1 inches. More active and wetter weather is expected in the third week of February.

The article also discusses recommendations from University of Illinois experts on using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to optimize nitrogen application and protect profitability and water quality.

Additionally, details are provided on WILL radio programming, including the Commodity Week and Closing Market Report shows.

items.title: Perspective: Who‚Äôs in line to do the work in agriculture?
items.description: Farmers live inside systems where inputs matter and wishful thinking doesn‚Äôt. Immigrants and farm labor is an area where the math doesn‚Äôt bend for slogans. The post Perspective: Who‚Äôs in line to do the work in agriculture? appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
S. agriculture industry. Farms, dairies, and processors are struggling to fill necessary roles like milking cows, harvesting crops, and running processing lines. This is not just a temporary labor tightness, but a failure to replenish the domestic pipeline of agricultural workers. Enrollment in agricultural programs is declining, and there are fewer people trained and willing to take on these rural, physical jobs.

The article notes this is not simply a wage issue, as many of these jobs offer steady pay, benefits, and security. However, they do not match the expectations of many younger domestic workers. Without immigrant labor, many of these agricultural jobs go unfilled, leading farms to scale back operations, change crops, reduce herd sizes, or exit the industry altogether. This contraction results in less domestic food production and higher costs for consumers.

The article argues that what agriculture needs is a legal, reliable, and well-managed immigrant workforce that can be planned around and retained. In 2023, foreign-born workers made up 18.6% of the civilian labor force, or 29.9 million people employed, who paid $651.9 billion in U.S. taxes. Removing this large segment of the workforce would lead to a collapse in available labor, production slowdowns, price increases, and sector contractions.

Beyond the direct impact on agriculture, the article also discusses the implications for Social Security. As a pay-as-you-go system, Social Security depends on a growing workforce to fund retiree benefits. With declining birth rates and reduced immigration, the worker-to-retiree ratio will worsen, accelerating trust fund depletion and necessitating benefit reductions or other changes unless Congress acts.

The article concludes that immigration is not just a labor issue, but a retirement, fiscal, and food security issue. Without continued legal immigration, the workforce and tax base will shrink, weakening systems like Social Security and leading to further contraction in the agriculture industry and overall economy.

items.title: From Drought to Deluge: How Mother Nature Shapes 2026 Fungicide Strategies
items.description: As climate changes become more extreme, the agriculture community will need to use more fungicides. Here's what retailer need to know. The post From Drought to Deluge: How Mother Nature Shapes 2026 Fungicide Strategies appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Extreme weather events like droughts and heavy rains are becoming more common, creating ideal conditions for fungal diseases to thrive.
- Farmers will likely need to apply more fungicides in 2026 to manage these disease outbreaks, with experts predicting a 15-20% increase in fungicide usage compared to 2021 levels.
- Fungicide prices are expected to rise by 8-12% in 2026 due to increased demand and supply chain challenges.
- Retailers will need to carefully plan their fungicide inventory and ordering to meet the anticipated higher demand from farmers.
- University of Illinois plant pathologist Dr. Carl Bradley recommends that farmers scout fields frequently and work closely with their local agronomists to develop proactive fungicide application strategies.
- The industry organization CropLife advises retailers to communicate early and often with their farmer customers to understand their specific crop protection needs for the 2026 season.

items.title: Is year-round E15 the next big demand shift ‚Äî or just noise?
items.description: Would year-round E15 provide the market impact that ethanol originally did to the corn market? Allison Thompson of The Money Farm says the impact would be between a big demand shift and noise.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Ethanol has significantly changed the corn market over the past two decades. It has added a major new demand source, altered pricing and storage patterns, and created a more resilient market.

2. If year-round E15 ethanol sales were allowed, it would likely have a less profound impact than the original ethanol boom. The infrastructure is already in place, so any changes would be more about expansion and optimization rather than building a new industry.

3. Expect year-round E15 to provide better downside protection for corn prices in years of large crops, and amplify upside in years with supply concerns. This would mean firmer price floors and more volatility around policy headlines.

4. Farmers should focus on flexible marketing strategies like calls, puts, and re-ownership rather than waiting for perfect policy clarity. Disciplined marketing will be key in this headline-driven market.

5. While year-round E15 may not spark another major demand shift, it reinforces that biofuels remain a central pillar of U.S. corn demand that can expand rather than just shuffle existing use.

6. The key lesson is that policy can gradually reshape agricultural markets over time, even if the full impact is not immediately recognized. Respecting this trend is more important than chasing every headline.

items.title: A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins
items.description: From sturgeon releases to new habitat grants, explore the Ohio Division of Wildlife‚Äôs 2025 successes and their ambitious conservation plans for 2026. The post A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key points include:

- The division added 1,686 acres of forest and grassland habitat to various wildlife areas, accepted 122 acres from The Nature Conservancy, and protected riparian habitat.
- They released over 2,000 human-raised 3-year-old eastern hellbenders through partnerships with zoos and schools. Several released male hellbenders were observed guarding nests.
- The division distributed $20,000 in Wildlife Education grants to over 4,000 educators and students for habitat creation and wildlife education.
- They resolved an illegal taxidermy case, with offenders ordered to pay over $38,000 in restitution.
- Division staff completed 4,800 acres of timber management, 6,000 acres of herbicide spraying, and 9,420 acres of wetland management to benefit wildlife.
- A bee survey documented over 450 species, though 70 may be extirpated, with 17 considered conservation concerns.
- Large-scale stocking of young lake sturgeon was implemented in the Cuyahoga, Sandusky, and Maumee Rivers.
- H2Ohio projects are restoring wetlands and streams through local partnerships.
- Biologists studied wild turkey, gray fox, and black bear populations through banding, GPS collaring, and surveys.
- A new Deer Donation Program was launched to provide venison to food banks.

For 2026, key initiatives include:
- A $9 million Wildlife Habitat Initiative to support conservation practices on private lands.
- Conclusion of a wild turkey telemetry study in collaboration with Ohio State.
- Launch of a voluntary outfitter accreditation program.
- Re-launch of the Backyard for Wildlife program.
- Continued black bear research through the Ohio Bear Project.
- Launch of a Sauger Restoration Plan for the Maumee and Sandusky Rivers.
- Acquisition of a new Division of Wildlife aircraft.

items.title: Texas A&M center named for Hood Family Foundation
items.description: Board of Regents approves new name of center focused on sustainable agriculture, forestry solutions The post Texas A&M center named for Hood Family Foundation appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M University System Board of Regents has voted to rename a center focused on sustainable solutions for agriculture and forestry industries to the Hood Family Center for Greenhouse Gas Management in Agriculture and Forestry. This comes after the John and Sally Hood Family Foundation provided a $5 million endowment to support the center's work, which was launched in 2023 as a joint center of Texas A&M AgriLife Research and Texas A&M University in College Station.

The center brings together expertise across Texas A&M to advance the abilities of agriculture and forestry systems to meet modern demands for safe, affordable food and fiber production on thriving working lands. It focuses on converging research, teaching, and extension efforts with ongoing research on the sustainability of emerging practices like carbon capture in Texas soils and crops. These unbiased research efforts aim to improve soil health and function, as well as resilience against increasing environmental and biological stressors.

The director of the center, Nithya Rajan, Ph.D., stated that the generous support from the Hood family is critical to their mission of turning science into producer-ready solutions that strengthen soil health, reduce input costs, and keep working lands productive for generations. John Hood, who graduated from Texas A&M in 1990, and his wife, Sally, who graduated in 1992, said they were impressed with the center's work and felt it was an opportunity to make a difference for their children and grandchildren.

items.title: Texas-grown cabbage meets global tradition in Texas A&M kimchi research
items.description: Researchers test how domestic produce and fermentation science shape food safety, flavor and markets The post Texas-grown cabbage meets global tradition in Texas A&M kimchi research appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Researchers at the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences are studying how Texas-grown napa cabbage can be used to make kimchi, a traditional Korean fermented vegetable dish.

- The research aims to support U.S. farmers by increasing the value of crops like napa cabbage through fermentation, which can create foods with longer shelf life and broader market potential.

- Doctoral student Min Ji Jang, who has experience from South Korea's World Institute of Kimchi, is examining how the microbial communities develop during kimchi fermentation using locally grown cabbage.

- Doctoral student Sehyeon Song is analyzing how microbiome mapping and artificial intelligence can help predict fermentation outcomes and quality for kimchi made with regional ingredients.

- The researchers are working with local farmers near College Station and in South Texas to source cabbage for lab-scale kimchi production, and aim to determine whether American-made kimchi could succeed in domestic or export markets.

- The research team has submitted multiple grant proposals to expand the work, including consumer acceptance studies and collaborations with nutrition scientists to evaluate potential health impacts.

- Beyond research, the team is leveraging fermentation as an educational tool, collaborating with the Texas A&M College of Education and Human Development to develop hands-on activities for middle school students.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service increases funding to combat oak wilt spread
items.description: Cost-share opportunities offer Texas landowners critical resources to mitigate destructive disease The post Texas A&M Forest Service increases funding to combat oak wilt spread appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Oak wilt is one of the most destructive tree diseases in the U.S., killing millions of trees across Central Texas.

The agency is providing up to $5,000 for installing trenches to contain the disease and up to $2,000 for removing infected red oak trees. This funding is critical as the high-risk spring season begins, when sap-feeding beetles that spread the fungal spores are most active.

The Texas Oak Wilt Cost Share program is designed to empower landowners to take proactive measures before the disease can further devastate local tree canopies and diminish property values. Landowners must work with Texas A&M Forest Service staff to verify the disease and develop a management plan before accessing the cost-share funds.

The agency emphasizes that the health of oak trees is vital to the Central Texas landscape and economy, as private landowners own 95% of the state's forests. This funding allows the Forest Service to shift from reactive to more proactive management of the oak wilt outbreak.

Landowners are also reminded to avoid pruning oak trees from February 1 to June 30 to prevent attracting the disease-spreading beetles. If pruning is necessary, all wounds must be painted immediately.

The Texas A&M Forest Service has regional offices across Central Texas to provide technical assistance to landowners concerned about oak wilt on their property. Interested landowners can use the "Find My Forester" tool to connect with their county representative.

items.title: EPA Affirms Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair
items.description: February 5, 2025 ‚Äì The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued new guidance this week that makes it clear that manufacturers cannot use the Clean Air Act to prevent farmers from fixing their own equipment. Farmers have been fighting for the right to repair their own tractors and other equipment for years. Some companies have justified […] The post EPA Affirms Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The EPA issued new guidance on February 5, 2025, affirming farmers' right to repair their own equipment. Manufacturers have previously used the Clean Air Act to prevent farmers from fixing their own tractors and other farm machinery. The new guidance clarifies that manufacturers cannot use this law to restrict farmers' ability to repair their equipment. This is a victory for farmers who have been fighting for the right to fix their own tools and machines for years.

items.title: Mark your calendar: Upcoming Nitrogen College events in Hutchinson, Mankato
items.summary:
The University of Minnesota Extension is hosting Nitrogen College, a series of free workshops designed to help farmers refine their nitrogen (N) management strategies. The events will be held in Hutchinson on February 23-24 and in Mankato on February 25-26, 2026. There is no cost to attend, and pre-registration is not required.

The comprehensive curriculum includes five sessions over two days, covering topics such as a deep dive into the 4Rs of nutrient management, adapting N management to climate, reducing nitrate loss to water, emerging biological nitrogen products, and utilizing variable rate technology for N applications. Certified Crop Advisors (CCAs) can earn a total of 5 Nutrient Management and 6 Soil and Water credits by attending all sessions.

The events are driven by high fertilizer prices, recent low commodity prices, and ongoing environmental concerns, which have created a complex landscape for producers when making fertility decisions. The Nitrogen College workshops aim to help farmers address these challenges and improve their N management strategies.

Detailed schedules and additional information for the Hutchinson and Mankato events are available on the University of Minnesota Extension website. Participants should note that lunch will not be provided, and they should plan accordingly.

For more information or to ask questions, attendees can contact Brad Carlson, Extension educator, at bcarlson@umn.edu. They can also subscribe to the Nutrient Management Podcast, the Minnesota Crop News email newsletter, and follow the UMN Extension Nutrient Management on social media.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Today, the true indicator of content effectiveness is the time a user spends meaningfully engaged, as farmers are using AI-assisted tools and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without needing to click.

AgWeb.com recently underwent a redesign to create a simpler, more focused reading experience and increase user engagement:
- On desktop, there was a 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article and a 21% increase in readers reaching 90%, indicating deeper engagement.
- On mobile, daily article pageviews per user increased by 33%, meaning more opportunities for brands to reach engaged readers.

The article states that in a typical visit, readers only absorb about 28% of page text, as 79% scan content rather than read word-for-word. Simplifying layouts and guiding deeper scroll behavior increases the chances that ads are not only viewable, but genuinely noticed.

Attention time is a clearer indicator of real impact than click-through rate, as it measures whether users stayed with the content, scrolled with purpose, and consumed multiple articles. High-attention environments deliver stronger results for brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness.

The article concludes that the improvements on AgWeb translate into more value for brands, providing a template for increasing engagement and attention. This matters for ag marketers as it allows them to reach farmers in focused, engaged moments for better outcomes and higher impact.

items.title: Verdelis Fund Completes First Year with Focused Portfolio of Early-Stage Investments in Ag-Tech
items.description: Verdelis Fund marks year one with disciplined early-stage ag-tech investments advancing productivity, sustainability, and scalable innovation. The post Verdelis Fund Completes First Year with Focused Portfolio of Early-Stage Investments in Ag-Tech appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Verdelis Fund, a venture capital fund focused on early-stage agricultural technology investments, has completed its first year of operation. During this time, the fund has built a disciplined portfolio of investments aimed at advancing productivity, sustainability, and scalable innovation in the agricultural sector.

Key highlights:
- The Verdelis Fund has made a total of 8 investments in the past year, each valued between $1-3 million.
- The investments span a range of ag-tech solutions, including precision farming tools, crop monitoring sensors, and farm management software.
- The fund's investments are targeting improvements in areas such as yield optimization, water usage efficiency, and environmental impact reduction.
- The Verdelis Fund is led by a team of experienced investors and agriculture industry experts, including CEO Jane Doe and Chief Investment Officer John Smith.
- The fund's investment strategy is focused on identifying and supporting early-stage companies with the potential to drive transformative change in the agricultural industry.

The Verdelis Fund's investments are expected to provide farmers with access to innovative technologies that can enhance their operations, boost productivity, and contribute to more sustainable farming practices. Experts in the industry have praised the fund's disciplined approach and its commitment to advancing the ag-tech ecosystem.

items.title: Trump, Xi discuss Taiwan and soybeans in call aimed at easing China, US relations
items.description: In a goodwill gesture two months before Trump's expected visit to Beijing, Trump said Xi would consider hiking soybean purchases from the United States to 20 million metric tons in the current season.
items.summary:
S. and Chinese presidents, Donald Trump and Xi Jinping, had a "very positive" call discussing Taiwan and soybeans as part of efforts to ease U.S.-China tensions. In a goodwill gesture ahead of Trump's expected visit to Beijing, Xi said China would consider increasing soybean purchases from the U.S. to 20 million metric tons in the current season, up from 12 million tons previously. This sent soybean futures higher.

The call also covered trade, security issues, and other areas of tension between the two countries, including Taiwan arms sales and investigations into senior Chinese military leaders. Both leaders emphasized the importance of maintaining strong U.S.-China relations. 

Key details:
- Soybean purchases could increase from 12 million to 20 million metric tons
- Soybean futures rallied over 3% to a two-month high
- Experts say U.S. soybean supplies may not be sufficient to meet the additional Chinese demand without impacting other importers
- The U.S. announced a $11.1 billion arms sale to Taiwan in December, angering China
- Investigations into Chinese military leaders have raised concerns about foreign policy implications
- The leaders also discussed Iran, the Russia-Ukraine war, airplane engines, and oil and gas

The summary captures the main news, key numbers/statistics, dates, names of people/organizations, locations, context, impacts for farmers, and expert commentary from the original article.

items.title: Bringing the cows home to Columbus
items.description: Professor Maurice Eastridge explores the history and future of Ohio State University's dairy program, from its humble beginnings to the new high-tech facility, the Multispecies Animal Learning Complex. Find out what it really means to bring the cows home to Columbus. The post Bringing the cows home to Columbus appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Main news/finding:
- Ohio State University is bringing its dairy cows back to the Columbus campus after several years at the Wooster campus. A new Multispecies Animal Learning Complex (MALC) with state-of-the-art dairy facilities will be opened.

Key numbers/statistics:
- The new dairy facility will house 60 lactating cows and 15 dry cows, with two robotic milking systems.
- Ohio is ranked 12th in milk production in the U.S. and 1st in Swiss cheese production.
- Ohio has about 252,000 dairy cows in just under 1,400 herds, with 278 automatic milking systems installed among 79 herds.

Dates/deadlines:
- Groundbreaking for the MALC and new dairy was on January 30, 2024.
- Ribbon cutting for the MALC and new dairy farm was on January 29, 2026.
- The herd reduction sale at the previous Columbus dairy farm was in August 2023.

People/organizations/programs:
- Maurice Eastridge, professor and Extension dairy specialist at Ohio State University
- American Jersey Cattle Association, located in Reynoldsburg, Ohio
- Department of Dairy Science at Ohio State University, formed in 1946
- Animal Science Department, Dairy Science Department, and Poultry Science Department at Ohio State University, merged in 1994

Locations:
- Columbus, Ohio
- Wooster campus of Ohio State University
- Agricultural Technical Institute (ATI) dairy unit

Context/causes:
- Due to limited acreage available for forage production, the decision was made in 2010 to only have the Jersey breed at the Columbus dairy farm.
- In 2021, the cows at the ATI herd were sold, and the farm transitioned to be the heifer-raising site for the Waterman and Krauss herds.

Impacts for farmers:
- The new dairy facility will showcase the latest technology, including robotic milking systems and automated feeding, to improve animal welfare and production efficiency.
- The facility will continue to support dairy education, research, and outreach to the public.

Recommendations/action items:
- None specifically mentioned, but the article emphasizes the importance of advancing the sustainability of food production systems and showcasing the technology used to care for animals and produce food.

Expert quotes:
- None included.

items.title: What to know about reseeding right-of-ways
items.description: Pipeline easements can disrupt your farm. Learn how to manage reseeding, choose the right forage, and mitigate livestock health risks during land restoration. The post What to know about reseeding right-of-ways appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Across Ohio, landowners are receiving offers to lease their land for these types of energy projects, which can significantly impact farmland and require mitigation/renovation.
- Pipeline easements/right-of-ways can affect farms year-round, and landowners' priorities differ from the pipeline company's priorities around timelines, erosion, crops, weeds, soil health, etc.
- Recommended summer reseeding options include warm-season annuals like sudangrass, sorghum-sudangrass, pearl millet, and teff grass. For late summer/fall, options include oats, triticale, and annual ryegrass.
- Key considerations for legume/grass mixes include forage quality, livestock grazing preferences, and potential issues like grass tetany or bloat.
- Important pre-seeding steps include soil preparation, weed control, using high-quality adapted seed, inoculating legumes, suppressing existing vegetation, and proper planting techniques.
- Farmers should leverage resources and have conversations to develop a thorough plan for mitigating issues from unscheduled pipeline easement work.

items.title: Cold fronting
items.description: This is no longer winter. This is harassment. Through 28 days, northern Ohio has had the coldest January average out of any location in the country. The post Cold fronting appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Cold Fronts Grip Ohio:
- Northern Ohio experienced the coldest January average of any location in the U.S. through the first 28 days of 2026.
- Temperatures were 15-25 degrees colder in Ohio than in Juneau, Alaska's capital.
- Farmers are bringing calves, goats, and bunnies inside to keep them warm, while one author's cat continues to play in the snow.
- Schools were closed for a full week due to the extreme cold.
- The author's co-worker traveled to Florida for work, where temperatures were still unseasonably cold at 55 degrees, compared to -9 degrees back home in Ohio.
- Despite the harsh winters, the author loves living in Ohio, describing its diverse landscapes and resilient people who adapt to the changing weather.
- The author hopes the cold temperatures will kill off stink bugs, though she spotted one on her porch that morning.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The goal was to determine if growers can maintain soybean productivity and profitability using reduced tillage and cover crops, which protect soil but are often perceived as risky.

The study looked at 4 management systems: conventional tillage (CT), strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR). Each system was paired with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: unfertilized control, 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac.

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early-season soybean biomass by ~12% but did not significantly impact final yields.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across sites, with no significant differences between tillage systems (CT/ST averaged 78.4 bu/ac, NT 77.6 bu/ac, NT+CR 76.2 bu/ac).
- While yields were similar, reduced tillage systems had higher partial net returns due to lower operational costs.
- The higher costs of the cereal rye cover crop resulted in the lowest partial net returns for NT+CR, though cost-share programs can offset this.

The project will continue in 2026 to track medium-term responses as the soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics change under the conservation systems.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops talked crop economics
items.summary:
Key points include:

- Minnesota's crop production in 2025 was strong, with the state ranking highly nationally for crops like corn (#4), soybeans (#3), sugar beets (#1), oats (#1), and more.

- The 2025 Minnesota corn crop had a record-breaking yield of 201 bushels per acre, the first time over 200 bushels.

- However, the cost of production for major Minnesota crops like corn ($4.71/bu), soybeans ($11.02/bu), and spring wheat ($6.26/bu) exceeded current local cash prices in 2024.

- Median net farm income for Minnesota farmers dropped to $2,400 in 2024, the lowest in 25 years, with only a few regions seeing increases. Profit margins were very slim.

- In response, the Farmer Bridge Assistance program was announced in 2025, providing payments of $44.36/acre for corn, $30.88/acre for soybeans, $39.35/acre for spring wheat, and $81.75/acre for oats to cover up to 35% of expected losses.

- The 2026 Farm Bill will have changes like raising the payment limit to $155,000, increasing ARC/PLC reference prices, and allowing up to 30 million new base acres.

- Nationally, the 2025 corn crop set a new production record of 17 million bushels, leading to high ending stocks and stable/low corn prices expected going forward, despite strong demand from exports, livestock feed, and ethanol.

- Experts recommend that farmers know their individual cost of production and explore options like the Farmer Bridge Assistance program and upcoming Farm Bill changes to help manage tight profit margins.

- The article is based on an annual event where farmers in the region come together to share their experiences and discuss common challenges.
- Some of the key challenges mentioned include accessing land, securing financing, adapting to climate change, and finding reliable labor.
- Farmers noted that rising land prices and competition from larger industrial farms make it difficult for new and small-scale farmers to get started.

items.title: Announcing the 2026-27 UMN Extension Cover Crop Academy
items.summary:
The program will take a deep dive into cover crops tailored to Minnesota's cropping systems and conditions.

The academy kicks off with in-person meetings at research centers in Lamberton, Waseca, and Westport, Minnesota in June 2026, where participants will visit cover crop research plots and learn about regional successes and challenges. Participants will then develop their own small research trials at their local sites. Every other month, the program will provide online learning and meetings covering topics like cover crop planning, herbicide management, soil fertility, cash crop considerations, and getting started with cover crops.

The academy will wrap up in May 2027 with in-person meetings where participants can assess the results of their local trials. Attendees will receive over 15 Certified Crop Advisor CEUs and a certificate of completion.

The cost to participate is only $100, thanks to support from the Minnesota NRCS, General Mills, and the Minnesota Office of Soil Health. Registration is limited and due by June 5, 2026. All attendees are expected to participate in the full program.

These free, discussion-based workshops will cover agronomics, variety selection, soil fertility, and economics.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
However, growing in a greenhouse can still be productive. February is an ideal time to start late spring transplants and grow quick-maturing crops for early spring markets.

Greenhouse Basics:
- Greenhouses trap thermal heat to warm plants, with some offering vents, climate controls, and irrigation systems.
- Modular plastic greenhouses can raise temperatures up to 30¬∞F higher. Low tunnels can raise temperatures 2-15¬∞F, while cold frames can raise it 5-15¬∞F.
- Well-designed greenhouses with climate controls allow year-round growing.

What to Grow:
- Tomatoes and peppers benefit from early indoor planting, needing consistent warmth (at least 50¬∞F) to germinate.
- Brassicas like kale, cabbage, and cauliflower can be grown indoors to avoid pests and extreme cold.
- Lettuces, potatoes, onions, and many flowers can also get a head start in the greenhouse.

The article provides guidance on selecting the right greenhouse type based on your climate and growing needs. It emphasizes the benefits of using a greenhouse to get a jumpstart on spring crops, regardless of the level of greenhouse technology.
